newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL short-term interbank rates fall due to maturity.
newsitem.headline: KL short-term interbank rates fall due to maturity.

text.p: Short-term interbank rates fell as liquidity improved further due to the maturity of a 420 million ringgit long-term government bond issue, dealers said on Wednesday.
They said the reaction to the maturity was muted because interbank rates have been declining in the last few days.
"There is not that much room for rates to fall," said a dealer with a Malaysian bank.
He said Bank Negara, to maintain a tight monetary policy, could intervene in the interbank market if rates fell sharply.
One-week money was at 6.50/80 percent against 6.80/7.00 on Tuesday, two-week at 7.00/10 percent against 7.10/20 and three-week at 7.10/20 percent against 7.10/25.
One-month money at 7.20/25 percent, three-month at 7.25/30 percent and six-month at 7.30/35 percent, were all steady.
Dealers said the overnight rate, which closed at 5.8/6.0 percent on Tuesday, was expected to remain unchanged.
They said the interbank rates were expected to fall further as more funds were expected to come in. On Friday, there is a maturity of 500 million ringgit in Bank Negara bills.
"Probably in anticipation of those maturities, people are holding back, waiting for rates to fall further," said a dealer with another Malaysian bank.
Interest rate futures on the Malaysia Monetary Exchange were mixed, futures dealers said.
The benchmark three-month Kuala Lumpur Interbank Offered Rate (KLIBOR) June contract was down two points at 92.66, or an implied yield of 7.34 percent.
But, September was steady at 92.67, or 7.32 percent, and December up one at 92.66, or 7.34 percent.
